node.title: ARTUROS
node.description:
Whitlock Design Group designed a new bar and function room in the first phase of the renovation, taking over two small neighboring tenants. Arturo’s was an existing, successful restaurant with a loyal following in Boston’s western suburbs. The space, however, did not represent the terrific food that it served. Capitalizing on their existing customer base, Domenico Fabiano, the owner wanted to expand his bar business and possibly extend his service hours, which ended early due to the suburban location.
The bar is a jewel box with an impressive collection of glittering crystal sphere pendants hanging from a gold ceiling. The black and gold color palette is both a connection to classic Italian design and modern aesthetics. The island bar is designed to be narrow and allow customers to feel connected across the bar and maintain a close, community feeling. The prominent wall of the bar display adds drama to the exciting design. The cozy booths are covered in black crushed velvet and there are gold toned mirrors in pyramidal shapes along the wall. 
The function room was an important part of the new program for Dom. He is regularly asked to celebrate occasions and have meetings in his restaurant but lacked the space for such large parties. He wanted a room that complimented the quality of his food and had character which is not found in most function venues. Large circular metal bands holding miniature LED lights add sparkle and interest to the space. A large art mural, designed by Whitlock Design Group and by mural artist, Mark Grundig, is a powerful presence on the space’s long walls. A large glass wall connects to the bar and function room and bar.
Dom asked Whitlock Design to create restrooms that were memorable and even Instagram-able. To that end, the entry to the restrooms are along a beautiful wall of long, curved, glossy, grooved black wall. At the restroom entry there is a glowing wall of shining gold geometric tiles. Inside the restrooms you are immediately greeted by an oversized image of paparazzi taking your photograph. The walls are adorned with more Whitlock/Grundig designed patterned wall murals.

node.title: MJ O’CONNOR'S RESTAURANT
node.description:
MJ O’Connor’s is a renovation of an existing bar in Boston’s Park Plaza. The space is an extension of the space that was underperforming. The new design relocates the entrance to the more prominent Park Plaza and create an exciting new prominent space. 
The design features a new island bar that is centered between beautiful groin vaulted ceilings. Traditional materials are interpreted in modern ways creating a restrained and beautiful space with a warm palette of colors. The large island bar features a Carrera marble top and mahogany base with floating glass shelves and beer taps. New chandeliers enhance the arched ceilings and whimsical artwork on the tall wooden paneled walls gives a nod to MJ’s Irish heritage, while being universal in its appeal.

node.title: PAGU
node.description:
Pagu is a restaurant featuring a fusion of Spanish and Asian food. Tracy Chang, the chef/owner, won of Boston Magazine’s ‘Best Chef’ award shortly after introducing Pagu to the Boston restaurant scene. The innovative design features a large display kitchen with a custom Hestan cooking suite, bounded by a live edge wooden counter and bar faced with Spanish tiles. The food is the show at Pagu and a huge skillet of paella or a large suckling pig are often part of the performance. 
The space is simply designed and is extremely flexible. Moveable wooden counters act as retail displays by day and bar tops by night and the space can be totally transformed to accommodate parties and weddings. Wood accents give warmth to the simple space with a warm and inviting bar and large curved beams to hold lighting. Accents and texture are created with Shou Sugi Ban wood, a traditional Japanese method of preserving wood by burning a thin layer of its surface.
The restaurant has been published in Travel + Leisure, Zagat, BonAppetit, Washington Post, Nikkei Asian, as well as the Boston Globe, Boston Magazine and Eater.

node.title: BEER WORKS
node.description:
Whitlock Design Group designed multiple locations as well as renovated existing spaces for Boston’s original microbrewery restaurant. The concepts feature the stainless-steel brewing equipment, sometimes elevated on industrial styled mezzanines, to animate the restaurants. 
The interior design is composed of creative metal finishes and large graphics in a simple and modern aesthetic. Large scaled lighting adds to the drama as well as fireplaces and firepits.

node.title: TRILLIUM BREWING COMPANY
node.description:
Trillium Brewing Company is a flagship brewery, beer hall, retail space and restaurant in the historic Fort Point Channel area. Trillium has become a world-renowned microbrewery and it’s beers are featured on lists of the world’s best beers. It had long since outgrown the tiny Boston location where it began their storied brewing. The Boston Wharf warehouse boasts a fabulous wooden timber structure and brick walls that seems to tell stories of Boston’s early rise as a prominent industrial city. A palette of wood, concrete and blackened steel creates wonderful textures throughout the space. 
The first floor is a beer hall, brewery and retail space that is designed with a large glazed wall behind its prominent bar that showcases the stainless tanks and wooden Foeder tanks. The beer making is the stage and patrons can watch the brewers as they enjoy a sip of some of the finest beers in the world. The design also allows for a queue of customers to purchase their beer, often sold in special releases that create large crowds of customers.
The second floor restaurant and function hall interiors highlight brick walls and wooden beam that create character and warmth to the dining spaces. A strong blackened steel and concrete stair connects the spaces with glimmering linear lights suspended from above. A window into the wood fired rotisserie and display promotes Trillium’s mission to use the freshest and finest of locally sourced ingredients. Signature lights fixtures hung in multiples and in strong geometric shapes help to bring a contemporary accent into the historic space.
A roof deck tops the location with an exciting festive space that overlooks the historic warehouses and the rising new construction in the surrounding Seaport area.

node.title: BAR RUSTIC
node.description:
Beer Works is a restaurant and brewery, serving American food and various micro-brews.  The design concept showcases the process of the working brewery, visible above the angled bar and dining areas.  Diamond plate accents, a stainless steel bar top, and black slate tile flooring reiterate the feel of a working brewery, while warm wood tones, large plush booths, and communal tables lend a warm and inviting environment.

Whitlock Design Group has designed locations in Hingham, Salem, Lowell, Boston (by Fenway) and at Logan Airport (two locations in Terminal C).

node.title: JAKE AND JOE'S
node.description:
Jake n Joe’s Sports Grille is your hometown sports restaurant and bar providing a comfortable atmosphere for diners and sports fans alike.  Reconstructed from the foundation up, the architecture of the exterior takes direction from historic American sports venues.  Expansive arched windows and detailed brick coursing mimic famous ballparks in the likes of Wrigley Field and Fenway Park.  Inside, the oversized bar takes center-stage with a ‘jumbotron’ of TVs above.  The exposed structure, industrial-style lighting, yet detailed millwork blend the concepts of restaurant and sports venue together cohesively.  The brick and plaster walls are adorned with iconic sports photography celebrating athletes past and present.  

Jake n Joe’s Sports Grille is located in Norwood MA.

node.title: THE CHATEAU
node.description:
The Chateau Restaurant has a long history of providing exceptional customer service, quality Italian cuisine, and a comfortable environment for diners of all ages.  A new location and recent renovations have provided the opportunity to enhance the design by integrating rich textures and patterns reminiscent of Sicilian villages.  Venetian plastered walls, rough brick veneers, and wine displays showcased within polished wood partitions provide a backdrop for the plush booths, layered ambient lighting, and scenic Italian artwork adorning the space.  Strategic television placement above the warm and welcoming bar, ensure that every seat is always occupied.                                                                                                            

Whitlock Design Group has designed Chateau Restaurants in Burlington, Waltham, Stoughton, and Norwood MA.
